title: The twins who tricked the Maya gods of death - Ilan Stavans

multiple-choice.question: What are the names of the two sets of twin brothers who played the ballgame in the story?

options.label: A
options.text: Jun and Wuqub, and Junajpu and Ixb’alanke

options.label: B
options.text: Junajpu and Ixb’alanke, and the Twin Lords

options.label: C
options.text: The Ballgame Brothers and the Twin Lords

options.label: D
options.text: Jun and Wuqub, and the Ballgame Brothers

multiple-choice.question: How did the lord's daughter become impregnated with Jun's offspring?

options.label: A
options.text: She ate the massive fruit from the tree

options.label: B
options.text: The skull of Jun spat on her hand

options.label: C
options.text: She was touched by a magical object from the underworld

options.label: D
options.text: She was cursed by the underworld lords

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: A map that led to the underworld

options.label: C
options.text: A magical amulet for protection

options.label: D
options.text: A warning from their grandmother about the underworld

options.label: A
options.text: They lit a fire to warm themselves

options.label: B
options.text: They adorned the torch with red macaw feathers and fireflies to make it appear lit

options.label: C
options.text: They used a magical spell to create light in the darkness

options.label: D
options.text: They hid among the statues of the lords

multiple-choice.question: Which supernatural trial did the twins survive by feeding bones to the beasts?

options.label: A
options.text: The House of Bats

options.label: B
options.text: The House of Jaguars

options.label: C
options.text: The House of Cold

options.label: D
options.text: The House of Darkness

options.label: B
options.text: A bat

options.label: C
options.text: A mosquito

options.label: D
options.text: A turtle shell

multiple-choice.question: How did the twins protect themselves from the wrath of the lords after winning the game?

options.label: A
options.text: They enlisted a pair of warriors for protection

options.label: B
options.text: They enlisted a pair of seers who helped them resurrect after being burned

options.label: C
options.text: They built a magical shield to deflect harm

options.label: D
options.text: They disguised themselves as two old men

multiple-choice.question: What was the final trick that the twins performed on the lords?

options.label: A
options.text: Ixb’alanke pretended to kill Junajpu, then resurrect him

options.label: B
options.text: The twins performed a dance and created illusions

options.label: C
options.text: The lords performed a trick on the twins

options.label: D
options.text: The twins turned the lords into animals

multiple-choice.question: What was the outcome of the twins' curse on the lords?

options.label: A
options.text: The lords were given more power over the surface world

options.label: B
options.text: The lords were allowed to continue sacrificing humans

options.label: C
options.text: The lords had no sacrifices and no power over the surface world

options.label: D
options.text: The lords were banished to a distant land

options.label: A
options.text: They were buried in the river

options.label: B
options.text: They were thrown in the river, which restored them to life

options.label: C
options.text: They were cremated and their ashes scattered

options.label: D
options.text: They were resurrected without the river's help

title: The sleep disorder you might not know you have - Alayna Vaughan

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary cause of snoring during sleep?

options.label: A
options.text: Congestion in the respiratory tract

options.label: B
options.text: Narrowing of the airway due to relaxed muscles around the soft tissues

options.label: C
options.text: Blockages in the airway caused by anatomical features

options.label: D
options.text: Increased airflow through the respiratory tract

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the sleep disorder characterized by loud, chronic snoring and pauses in breathing during sleep?

options.label: A
options.text: Central sleep apnea

options.label: B
options.text: Obstructive sleep apnea

options.label: C
options.text: Respiratory sleep disorder

options.label: D
options.text: Sleep apnea syndrome

multiple-choice.question: What are common symptoms of obstructive sleep apnea?

options.label: A
options.text: Loud snoring

options.label: B
options.text: Pauses in breathing during sleep

options.label: C
options.text: Difficulty breathing and poor-quality rest

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

multiple-choice.question: What are risk factors for developing obstructive sleep apnea?

options.label: A
options.text: Drinking alcohol before going to sleep and weight gain

options.label: B
options.text: Larger tongues and thicker necks

options.label: C
options.text: Older age and smaller jaws

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

multiple-choice.question: What is a common and reliable treatment for obstructive sleep apnea?

options.label: A
options.text: CPAP machines

options.label: B
options.text: Surgery

options.label: C
options.text: Mouth and throat exercises

options.label: D
options.text: Oral appliances

multiple-choice.question: What are the effects of obstructive sleep apnea on the body?

options.label: A
options.text: Increased oxygen intake and reduced stress

options.label: B
options.text: Increased blood pressure and stress on the heart

options.label: C
options.text: Decreased concentration and chronic fatigue

options.label: D
options.text: Both B and C

multiple-choice.question: What is a significant contributor to obstructive sleep apnea?

options.label: A
options.text: Drinking alcohol before going to sleep

options.label: B
options.text: Larger tongues and thicker necks

options.label: C
options.text: Older age

options.label: D
options.text: Weight gain, as it can constrict the airway

multiple-choice.question: What is a preliminary trial treatment for mild obstructive sleep apnea?

options.label: A
options.text: CPAP machines

options.label: B
options.text: Surgery

options.label: C
options.text: Mouth and throat exercises

options.label: D
options.text: Oral appliances

multiple-choice.question: What are common behavioral approaches to alleviate obstructive sleep apnea?

options.label: A
options.text: Limiting alcohol consumption before bed

options.label: B
options.text: Elevating the head

options.label: C
options.text: Avoiding sleeping on the back

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

multiple-choice.question: What is often considered a last resort for treating obstructive sleep apnea after non-invasive treatments have failed?

options.label: A
options.text: CPAP machines

options.label: B
options.text: Surgery

options.label: C
options.text: Mouth and throat exercises

options.label: D
options.text: Oral appliances

title: 3 secrets of resilient people - Lucy Hone

options.text: To study the effects of trauma on civilians

options.label: B
options.text: To develop strategies for boosting physical fitness in soldiers

options.label: C
options.text: To develop strategies for boosting mental resilience in soldiers

options.label: D
options.text: To research the causes of mental illness in the general population

options.label: A
options.text: They felt hopeful and supported by the advice

options.label: B
options.text: They felt overwhelmed and powerless to control their grief

options.label: C
options.text: They felt confused and uncertain about the advice

options.label: D
options.text: They felt angry and resistant to the advice

options.label: A
options.text: It helps people avoid taking risks and facing challenges

options.label: B
options.text: It leads to increased anxiety and stress

options.label: C
options.text: It helps people stop feeling discriminated against when they experience adversity

options.label: D
options.text: It promotes a sense of hopelessness

options.label: A
options.text: They focus too much on the positive aspects of life

options.label: B
options.text: They focus too much on the negative aspects of life, which can be overwhelming

options.label: C
options.text: They focus too much on the present moment and neglect the past and future

options.label: D
options.text: They focus too much on internal experiences and neglect external events

options.label: A
options.text: Those who participated showed lower levels of gratitude and happiness

options.label: B
options.text: Those who participated showed higher levels of gratitude and happiness

options.label: C
options.text: Those who participated showed no change in their emotional state

options.label: D
options.text: Those who participated showed increased levels of depression and anxiety

options.label: A
options.text: It helps people avoid making mistakes and taking risks

options.label: B
options.text: It leads to increased self-doubt and uncertainty

options.label: C
options.text: It helps people take control of their decision-making and make intentional choices

options.label: D
options.text: It promotes a sense of hopelessness

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the reminder to "accept" the good, as mentioned by the speaker?

options.label: A
options.text: To help people avoid negative thoughts and emotions

options.label: B
options.text: To help people focus on the negative aspects of life

options.label: C
options.text: To help people remember to be grateful for the good things in their life

options.label: D
options.text: To promote a sense of entitlement

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the benefit of being able to switch the focus of one's attention to include the good?

options.label: A
options.text: It helps people avoid feeling depressed and anxious

options.label: B
options.text: It leads to increased denial and avoidance

options.label: C
options.text: It helps people find things to be grateful for and appreciate the good in their life

options.label: D
options.text: It promotes a sense of hopelessness

options.label: A
options.text: It helped them avoid feeling overwhelmed and anxious

options.label: B
options.text: It helped them take control of their decision-making and make intentional choices

options.label: C
options.text: It led to increased self-blame and guilt

options.label: D
options.text: It promoted a sense of hopelessness

options.label: A
options.text: That resilience is a fixed trait that some people have and some people don't

options.label: B
options.text: That resilience requires very ordinary processes and can be developed by anyone

options.label: C
options.text: That resilience is only for people who have experienced trauma and adversity

options.label: D
options.text: That resilience is not important for everyday life and is only necessary in extreme circumstances

options.label: A
options.text: They followed the advice of experts

options.label: B
options.text: They ignored the advice and did nothing

options.label: C
options.text: They decided to conduct a self-experiment to find ways to cope with their grief

options.label: D
options.text: They sought out additional advice from other experts

options.label: A
options.text: Avoiding challenges and risks

options.label: B
options.text: Focusing on the negative aspects of life

options.label: C
options.text: Practicing gratitude and appreciation for the good things in life

options.label: D
options.text: Ignoring one's emotions and thoughts

multiple-choice.question: What did the speaker learn from their experience of coping with grief?

options.label: A
options.text: That resilience is a fixed trait that some people have and some people don't

options.label: B
options.text: That resilience requires very ordinary processes and can be developed by anyone

options.label: C
options.text: That it is impossible to cope with grief and trauma

options.label: D
options.text: That seeking advice from experts is the best way to cope with grief

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the benefit of acknowledging that adversity is a natural part of life?

options.label: A
options.text: It helps people avoid taking risks and facing challenges

options.label: B
options.text: It leads to increased anxiety and stress

options.label: C
options.text: It helps people stop feeling discriminated against when they experience adversity

options.label: D
options.text: It promotes a sense of hopelessness

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea of the speaker's talk?

options.label: A
options.text: To discuss the causes of mental illness

options.label: B
options.text: To share strategies for building resilience and coping with adversity

options.label: C
options.text: To talk about the importance of seeking advice from experts

options.label: D

title: The secrets of the world’s most famous symphony - Hanako Sawada

title: The simplest math problem no one can solve

multiple-choice.question: What is the Collatz conjecture, and what does it propose about positive integers?

options.label: A
options.text: It proposes that every positive integer will eventually end up in a random number.

options.label: B
options.text: It proposes that every positive integer will eventually end up in a loop of any size.

options.label: C
options.text: It proposes that every positive integer will eventually end up in a specific mathematical structure other than the four, two, one loop.

options.label: D
options.text: It proposes that every positive integer will eventually end up in the four, two, one loop.

multiple-choice.question: What are "hailstone numbers," and how are they generated?

options.label: A
options.text: They are numbers generated by applying the 3x+1 rules to a given number, but only for even numbers.

options.label: B
options.text: They are numbers generated by applying the 3x+1 rules to a given number, but only for odd numbers.

options.label: C
options.text: They are numbers generated by applying a random mathematical operation to a given number.

options.label: D
options.text: They are numbers generated by applying the 3x+1 rules to a given number.

multiple-choice.question: Why do the paths that different numbers take in the Collatz conjecture vary so widely?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the 3x+1 rules are random and unpredictable.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the numbers themselves are random and unpredictable.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the 3x+1 rules are deterministic, but the sequences are short and simple.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the 3x+1 rules are deterministic, but the sequences are long and complex.

multiple-choice.question: What is Benford's law, and what does it describe?

options.label: A
options.text: It describes the distribution of the leading digit of a number, which is always 1.

options.label: B
options.text: It describes the distribution of the leading digit of a number, which is always 9.

options.label: C
options.text: It describes a random distribution of the leading digit of a number.

options.label: D
options.text: It describes a specific distribution of the leading digit of a number, which follows a predictable pattern.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the scatterplot in the context of the Collatz conjecture?

options.label: A
options.text: To show that every number in the sequence is larger than the original seed.

options.label: B
options.text: To show that every number in the sequence is smaller than the original seed.

options.label: C
options.text: To show that almost all numbers in the sequence are larger than the original seed.

options.label: D
options.text: To show that almost all numbers in the sequence are smaller than the original seed.

multiple-choice.question: Why is it challenging to prove the Collatz conjecture true?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it is a simple problem that lacks complexity.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it is a complex problem that lacks a clear pattern or structure.

options.label: C
options.text: Because despite much effort, no one has found a proof or counterexample.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the problem is proven to be undecidable.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the graph of the Collatz conjecture?

options.label: A
options.text: It shows that every number in the sequence is disconnected from the main graph.

options.label: B
options.text: It shows that every number in the sequence is connected to the main graph.

options.label: C
options.text: It shows the intricate, organic-looking structure of the Collatz conjecture.

options.label: D
options.text: It shows a random distribution of numbers.

multiple-choice.question: Why is it difficult to search for a counterexample to the Collatz conjecture?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the space of all possibilities is too small to search exhaustively by brute force.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the space of all possibilities is random and unpredictable.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the space of all possibilities is too big to search exhaustively by brute force.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the problem is proven to be undecidable.

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between the Collatz conjecture and the halting problem?

options.label: A
options.text: The Collatz conjecture is a problem that can be solved by a computer, while the halting problem is a problem that cannot be solved by a computer.

options.label: B
options.text: The Collatz conjecture is a problem that cannot be solved by a computer, while the halting problem is a problem that can be solved by a computer.

options.label: C
options.text: The Collatz conjecture is not related to the halting problem.

options.label: D
options.text: The Collatz conjecture is related to the halting problem, and it is possible that it is undecidable.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main takeaway from the discussion of the Collatz conjecture?

options.label: A
options.text: That the Collatz conjecture is a simple problem that can be solved by a computer.

options.label: B
options.text: That the Collatz conjecture is a complex problem that cannot be solved by a computer.

options.label: C
options.text: That the Collatz conjecture is a problem that can be understood and explored by anyone.

options.label: D
options.text: That the Collatz conjecture is a problem that is not worth studying.

title: What few people know about the program that "saved" America - Meg Jacobs

options.label: D
options.text: Utanapishti, the immortal man

multiple-choice.question: What type of plant did Gilgamesh retrieve, which granted eternal youth?

options.label: A
options.text: A magical flower from the Garden of the Gods

options.label: B
options.text: A plant from the Mountains of the Gods

options.label: C
options.text: A magical herb from the Forest of Cedar

options.label: D
options.text: A magical plant that grew at the bottom of the ocean

multiple-choice.question: Who stole the magical plant from Gilgamesh?

options.label: A
options.text: Enkidu, his friend and companion

options.label: B
options.text: Utanapishti, the immortal man

options.label: C
options.text: Shiduri, the goddess and bartender

options.label: D
options.text: A snake

multiple-choice.question: What did Gilgamesh write on a lapis lazuli tablet and bury under the city walls?

options.label: A
options.text: The Tale of Enkidu and the Bull of Heaven

options.label: B
options.text: The Story of Uruk and its people

options.label: C
options.text: A poem about his adventures

options.label: D
options.text: His own story, the Epic of Gilgamesh
